text: Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact signed. It creates spheres of influence between Germany and Russia in Eastern Europe.
Germany Invades Poland. Two days later GB and France declare war on Germany. WW2 Begins.
Germany's forces are fairly weak in the west. But France and GB do not attack. They wait for Poland to wear down Germany.
Using a combination of tanks, planes, and tactics popularly known 'Blitzkrieg' Poland surrenders. German forces move to the west.
Russia invades Poland from the West.
Both sides wait for major combat. This period is known as the 'Sitzkieg' or Phony war'.
Germany invades Norway to protect Swedish iron ore shipments from Allied attack.

Germany invades France and Benelux countries. Within weeks, in the middle of the campaign, luftwaffe planes relocate to France south of the Meuse river. They are able to continue direct support to the advancing army.
France loses the campaign and surrenders in 6 weeks. GB forces evacuate the continent at Dunkirk.
GB alone continues the fight without any end in sight. Germany moves luftwaffe to the edge of France to conduct the worlds first strategic air campaign - The Battle of Britain.

Gaining air superiority was a necesary first step to launch a seaborn attack on Britain but the Luftwaffe could not defeat the RAF. Unescorted, attacking bombers were found to be particularly vulnerable against intercepting fighters. The lack of a long-range fighter escort will be a problem for USAAF the later half of 1943.
Germany postpones invasion of Britain indefinitely. Italy invades Greece.

Luftwaffe sent to Sicily to help the Italians. While the Mediterranean and North African campaigns were considered 'strategic backwaters' for Germany they will consume sizeable Luftwaffe forces in the coming years.

Germany invades Yugoslavia and Greece to help Italy, protect the 'southern flank', and to prevent allies using these locations to bomb Romanian oil. Like the campaigns in Norway, France, and Poland these are short campaigns lasting only a few weeks.
Large build up of 'last minute' Luftwaffe forces in Poland.
Germany invades Russia in the largest invasion in history. A majority of planes are deployed on the Eastern Front and it will remain the focus until the midle 1943.
Within days the Luftwaffe destroys thousands of Soviet planes and achieves air superiority. The Luftwaffes main task now is supporiting ground operations.
Milllions of POWs are captured in massive encirclement operations (most starved in open air prisons). The luftwaffe showed it's adaptability by relocating to new airfields and supporting the army.
But the large advancments of the Wermacht also lay bare its deficiencies in logistical support and maintaining operational capabilities over vast distances.
By the winter the German advance is struggling. Large scale German (over 900k) casualites and unpreparedness of winter conditions (machines are too cold to start) halt the advance outside Moscow.
Russia launches a counter attack. The Battle of Moscow is one of the largest battles in the war it signifies the end of quick campaigns. It is now a war of attrition.
Germany Declares War on US. Air units arrive in Sicily to help protect Axis shipping from Allied attack.

Britain launches the first 1000 bomber raid of war on Cologne. Lacking a long-range fighter to escort bombers the English focus on night attacks aimed at destorying the Germans will to fight. Known as 'area' or 'terror' bombing this is a central part of UK's offensive strategy.

The ability to fly across large distances on short notice made the Luftwaffe an integral part in waging war and 'plugging the gaps' when they arose. The Russian attack in Kharkov was stopped in large part by Luftwaffe bombers quickly flying from the Crimea to assist in ground operations.
Germany, concerned about oil production, attacks far into Southern Russia to capture the Caucasian oil fields.
Germans capture the Caucasian oil fields but could not be exploited as they were destroyed by the retreating Russians. The focus of attack was on capturing the city of Stalingrad.
Second Battle of El Alamein near Cairo marks the end of German territorial advances in the Western Fronts. This coincides closely with the fartheset German forces advanced in the East.
Germans made it to Grozny oil fields but could not be exploited as they were destroyed by the retreating Soviets. The focus of attack was on capturing the city of Stalingrad.

The Luftwaffe fights in three major fronts; Invasion of Sicily, Kursk, and Defense of the Reich. While the vast majority of the army is in the Eastern Front Germany allocates more and more Luftwaffe resources to the West from this point on.

US and GB forces land in North Africa. As French forces collapsed against allied attacks Germany occupies Vichy France and Tunisia. Since the Italian navy could not send shipments in British dominated waters the Luftwaffe is continually relied upon to transport supplies to North Africa.
By the middle of the month the Stalingrad pocket lost it's major airfield to Russian attacks.
German forces in Stalingrad surrender. Russia continues it's attack.
Germany counterattacks and stablizes the front. This is the last meaningful German victory on the Eastern Front creating a salient at Kursk.
Operation Flax an allied attack on Nazi transport planes supplying Tunisia. While the number of planes are relatively small in the Mediterranean allied air attacks inflict consistant and high losses.
Additional Fighters are stationed in Western Germany to fight the USAAF daylight attacks. USAAF priority is to attain air supremecy for the Allied invasion of France set to happen next year.
Largest tank battle in history at Kursk. The lufwaffe assists but no longer has air supremecy in the East.
German attack faulters and the Russian counter attack at Kursk sees the Germans retreating from Central Russia.

The Luftwaffe fights in three major fronts; Invasion of Sicily, Kursk, and Defense of the Reich. While the vast majority of the army is in the Eastern Front Germany will allocate more and more Luftwaffe resources to the West from this point.
Germany occupies Italy after Italian surrender. Due to the mountainous terrain the Germans are able to hold on and fight the Allied offensive with relatively small numbers of troops and planes.
Allies land in in Southern Italy. Due to the mountainous terrain the Germans are able to hold on and fight the Allied offensive with relatively small numbers of troops and planes.

USAAF routinely sends mass formations of bombers (300+) to bomb factories in Germany. Outside the range of fighter escort the Germans counter by arranging large scale formation of interceptors and inflict heavy casualties on the invading bombers. USAAF pauses bombing in Germany.
The advant of the P-51 and drop tanks a the end of 1943 provide the allies with a long range escort necessary to fly bombing missions into Germany with acceptable losses.

The effectivenss of the combined strategic bombing campaigns of USAAF and RAF continued to be debated to this day. What can not be debated is the large scale shift in focus to meet these threats. Additional fighters are stationed to protect the reich and bombers are stationed in France for revenge attacks on England.
USAAF launches Operation Argument with the goal to minimise the ‘Production-wastage’ differential by attacking both the factories on the ground and Luftwaffe in the air.

Due to efficiency gains made in the prior years German fighter production increases. USAAF now focus on maximizing the ‘wastage’ of german pilots in combat by luring Luftwaffe up to fight with attacks on Berlin.
Luftwaffe pilot attrition is high and quality of new pilots decreases steadily. USAAF launches attack on German synthetic fuel production which will reduce operations in coming months.

Luftwaffe sends hundreds of fighters into France to fight the Allied invasion of Normandy. Many more Allied aircraft can fly over France than Germany and the Luftwaffe is mauled with well over 100% loss rates.
Russia attacks with Operation Bagration and large numbers of Germans are surrounded and taken prisoner. It is the largest defeat in German military history.

Russian troops nearly make it to Warsaw. Polish nationalists within the city stage the Warsaw Uprising expecting Russian aid. It does not come. It's said that Stalin is more interested in the post war world than a quick defeat of Nazi Germany. The Germans crush the uprising.
Allies break out of Normandy.
Germans encircled in the Falaise pocket. Most of German forces and Luftwaffe retreat to Germany.

Combined allied forces launch a large scale airborne attack in Holland to capture a series of bridges to Germany. It proves to be a "bridge too far". USAAF attacks on Germany continue after supporting Normandy Invasion.

Luftwaffe stil loses hundreds of planes a month in the air campaign against the USAAF. The interesting thing about this is that it's not really mentioned in history books. Allied air forces are so large that even this relatively large scale resistance isn't noteworthy.

Fighters move to Western Germany and support the German offensive known as the Battle of the Bulge. Even with this build up in forces Germany knows it won't have air supremacy so it waits until poor weather to attack.

Operatoin Bodenplatte sees a suprise attack on allied airfields in France to support Battle of the Bulge. Inflicting damage to the allies it proved to be pyrhic.   It was the last large scale air offensive of the Luftwaffe.
Focus is on the Balkans with takeover of Bulgaria, Romania, and Hungary in the coming months.
Budapest falls to Soviet armies.
Battle of Berlin. April 30 Hitler commits suicide. Some fighting continued until unconditional German surrender on May 8, 1945.
